choices.text:
They had been through so much together, and they loved each other more than anything. They had fought and loved and fought some more, and they had never been able to stay away from each other for long. They were happy together, and they knew that they would never be able to be apart.

Explanation: This story has indirect characterization because it never explicitly states that the two protagonists are in love. Rather, the story describes their actions and thoughts which lead to the inference that they are lovers. For example, the line “they had never been able to stay away from each other for long” suggests a deep level of love and commitment.

They had been through so much together, and they loved each other deeply. They had shared everything with each other, and there was nothing they wouldn't do for each other. They were always there for each other in the good times and the bad. They were true soulmates.

Explanation: This story about lovers has indirect characterization because it describes the protagonists through indirect details. These indirect details include the couple’s actions of “sharing everything with each other” and being “there for each other in the good times and the bad”.

Though they had been dating for over a year, John and Jane still acted like giddy school children around each other. They were always holding hands and stealing kisses when they thought no one was looking. They loved to surprise each other with little gifts, and they were always making plans for the future. It was clear to everyone that they were madly in love.

Explanation: This story about John and Jane has indirect characterization because it describes the protagonists “John” and “Jane” through indirect details. These indirect details include Jane’s action of “stealing kisses when they thought no one was looking”, and John and Jane’s shared quality of “always making plans for the future”.

They had been through so much together, and they had come out the other side stronger for it. They loved each other deeply, but they also loved the excitement of the unknown. They were always drawn to each other, even when they were exploring other relationships. They were each other's home, and they knew that no matter what happened, they would always find their way back to each other.

Explanation: This story about lovers has indirect characterization because it describes the protagonists “they” through indirect details. These indirect details include “always drawn to each other” and “each other's home”.

They had been through so much together, and they loved each other deeply. They knew each other's secrets, and they had seen each other at their worst. They had fought and made up, and they had laughed and cried together. They were soulmates, and they knew that they would be together forever.

Explanation: This story about lovers has indirect characterization because it describes the protagonists through indirect details. These indirect details include the characters’ actions of “fighting and making up” and “laughing and crying together”. These details reveal that the protagonists are deeply in love with each other.

Though they had only been dating for a few months, John and Jane were already in love. They were always together, whether they were going on walks, cooking dinner, or just watching TV. They were always laughing and joking, and they could never get enough of each other. They were always touching, kissing, and cuddling. It was clear to everyone that they were head-over-heels in love.

Explanation: This story has indirect characterization because it uses descriptions of John and Jane’s actions to describe them as a couple in love. These actions include “always being together”, “laughing and joking”, and “touching, kissing, and cuddling”.

They had been through so much together, and they loved each other deeply. They had laughters and tears, and they were always there for each other through it all. They knew each other's hopes and dreams, and they were determined to make them all come true. They were the perfect match, and they knew it.

Explanation: This story about lovers has indirect characterization because it describes the protagonists “They” through indirect details. These indirect details include “always being there for each other” and “knowing each other's hopes and dreams”.

They had been through so much together, and they loved each other deeply. They knew each other's secrets, hopes, and dreams. They were always there for each other, no matter what. They were each other's everything, and they couldn't imagine life without the other.

They had been through so much together, and nothing could tear them apart. They had seen each other at their worst and their best, and they loved each other all the same. They were always there for each other, no matter what. They were each other's home.

They had been through so much together, and they loved each other deeply. They had laughed together, and they had cried together. They had fought, and they had made up. They had been through the highest of highs and the lowest of lows, and they had come out the other side stronger than ever. They were each other's best friend, and they knew that they could always count on each other, no matter what.
